issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) incorrectly says that the PersonController methods take a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter. The template and solution PersonController method signatures use Consumer<List<Person>>. This is a typo in the problem description and can confuse students about the correct generic type they must use when implementing the controller methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to say that each PersonController method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter (not Consumer<List<Note>>), so it matches the template and solution signatures and avoids student confusion.

issues.description: The solution implementation of PersonController.addPerson uses a synchronous blocking call (bodyToMono(...).block()). The problem statement explicitly requires that HTTP requests happen asynchronously and each method should only send a single HTTP request. The blocking call in the solution contradicts the stated asynchronous design and is annotated in the solution as an "ARCHITECTURAL VIOLATION." Students comparing template, specification and solution may be confused about the intended non-blocking/reactive approach.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the solution to use a non-blocking reactive flow consistent with the rest of the controllers (e.g., remove .block() and use retrieve().bodyToMono(Person.class).onErrorStop().subscribe(...)), so the addPerson method performs the HTTP request asynchronously and updates the internal persons list in the subscribe callback. Also remove the blocking comment to avoid presenting a conflicting example.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, method contract description) says “Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter” while both the template and the solution declare the PersonController methods to accept `Consumer<List<Person>>`. This is a cross-artifact naming mismatch (likely a copy-paste typo) that can confuse students about the expected generic type for the callback: the text implies Note objects but the actual API expects Person objects.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController method callbacks, so the textual specification matches the template and solution signatures and avoids confusion.
